item.title: Review: ‘Blade Runner 2049’ Tries to Honor the Original and to Slip Free of It
item.media:description: Ryan Gosling stars in “Blade Runner 2049,” directed by Denis Villeneuve.
item.description: Denis Villeneuve dares a sequel to Ridley Scott’s dystopian classic from 1982.
item.dc:creator: A. O. SCOTT

item.title: Can Hollywood Movies About Climate Change Make a Difference?
item.media:description: Jennifer Lawrence in “Mother!”
item.description: To galvanize audiences: Don’t use apocalyptic plots. But a dose of humor? That might help.
item.dc:creator: MELENA RYZIK

item.title: Wonders in a Grim World: The New York Film Festival’s Best Trick
item.media:description: Jason Mitchell, left, and Garrett Hedlund in the Dee Rees drama “Mudbound.”
item.description: New movies from Todd Haynes, Woody Allen, Claire Denis and Dee Rees are among the highlights of the festival’s second half.
item.dc:creator: A.O. SCOTT
item.category: On the Beach at Night Alone (Movie)

item.title: Roman Polanski Accused of Rape by Former German Actress
item.media:description: Renate Langer in Munich.
item.media:credit: Louisa Marie Summer for The New York Times
item.description: The former German actress, Renate Langer, said she was raped at 15 in a house in Switzerland where she had gone in hopes of getting a part in a film.
item.dc:creator: SOPHIE HAIGNEY

item.title: Review: Robert Redford and Jane Fonda Are Neighbors With Benefits in ‘Our Souls at Night’
item.media:description: Jane Fonda and Robert Redford in “Our Souls at Night,” directed by Ritesh Batra.
item.description: This small-town romance was adapted from the novel by Kent Haruf.
item.dc:creator: A. O. SCOTT

item.title: Audrey Hepburn Shines at Auction, but Celebrity Sales Are Changing
item.media:description: The Vivien Leigh stardust inspired a succession of high prices at Sotheby’s on Tuesday.
item.description: The actress’s “Breakfast at Tiffany’s” script fetched a hefty price at a marathon auction, but whether today’s celebrities will ever have the same draw remains to be seen.
item.dc:creator: SCOTT REYBURN

item.title: Review: ‘American Made’ Has Tom Cruise. And Lies, Spies and Coke.
item.media:description: Tom Cruise as the real-life smuggler Barry Seal in “American Made.”
item.description: Mr. Cruise plays a real-life pilot turned smuggler who worked for the C.I.A., in Doug Liman’s new movie.
item.dc:creator: MANOHLA DARGIS

item.title: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Blade Runner 2049’
item.description: Denis Villeneuve narrates a sequence from his film featuring Ryan Gosling.

item.title: Review: In ‘Mark Felt,’ Liam Neeson Is the Man Known as Deep Throat
item.media:description: Liam Neeson as Mark Felt, the F.B.I. figure who was instrumental in helping to unravel Watergate.
item.description: Peter Landesman’s accidentally timely Watergate procedural has men in suits fighting for the independence of the F.B.I.
item.dc:creator: A. O. SCOTT
item.category: Mark Felt: The Man Who Brought Down the White House (Movie)

item.title: New Trailer: ‘Wonder Wheel’ From Woody Allen
item.media:description: Justin Timberlake in the new Woody Allen film “Wonder Wheel.”
item.description: Set on Coney Island, the drama, with Juno Temple, Kate Winslet and Justin Timberlake, appears to be his most New York-centric film in years.
item.dc:creator: BRUCE FRETTS

item.title: Neighborhood Joint: A Backyard Film Festival in Astoria, Queens
item.media:description: A recent screening of “Who Framed Roger Rabbit” at the home of Frank Zagottis, the organizer of the Newtown Road Backyard Film Festival in Astoria, Queens.
item.media:credit: Gareth Smit for The New York Times
item.description: For 11 years, a passionate film buff has been inviting neighbors to watch movie classics on a piece of large fabric that hangs behind his house.
item.dc:creator: JOHN SURICO

item.title: Feature: A Former Superagent Bets Big on a More Diverse Hollywood
item.media:description: Charles D. King
item.media:credit: Awol Erizku for The New York Times
item.description: After years as the industry’s top African-American talent agent, Charles D. King is building an audacious new production company — with a vision for bringing long-neglected stories to the screen.
item.dc:creator: CALVIN BAKER

item.title: With... Idris Elba: Able Was I Ere I Saw Elba! Actor Opines on Sex, Race, Bond
item.media:description: Idris Elba at the Mandarin Oriental hotel in New York.
item.description: He does not look away at his phone, the waitress, his publicists or his steak salad. His expressive brown eyes are always on you. Or in this case, me.
item.dc:creator: MAUREEN DOWD

item.title: Review: ‘Chavela’ Recalls the Life of the Ranchera Singer Chavela Vargas
item.media:description: Chavela Vargas in the documentary “Chavela,” whose centerpiece is footage of Ms. Vargas speaking for herself, in material shot in 1991.
item.description: The documentary about the singer Chavela Vargas provides a biography, but doesn’t give a strong sense of the musician’s power.
item.dc:creator: BEN KENIGSBERG

item.title: Feature: Frances McDormand’s Difficult Women
item.media:credit: Katy Grannan for The New York Times
item.description: The actor has built a career, and a passionate fan base, playing supporting roles; now, at 60, she has become an unconventional star.
item.dc:creator: JORDAN KISNER

item.title: Denis Villeneuve Narrates a Scene From ‘Blade Runner 2049’
item.description: The director discusses a sequence featuring Ryan Gosling.
item.dc:creator: MEKADO MURPHY

item.title: Tom Cruise’s ‘American Made’ Plays Second Fiddle to ‘It’
item.media:description: Tom Cruise plays a drug runner in “American Made,” which cost roughly $55 million to make.
item.media:credit: David James/Universal Pictures, via Associated Press
item.description: “American Made” gave Mr. Cruise one of the lowest opening-weekend box office results of his career. Its backers hope for strong interest in the weeks ahead.
item.dc:creator: BROOKS BARNES

item.title: Production of a Lifetime: Whitney Houston and Clive Davis
item.media:description: Clive Davis and Whitney Houston signing her contract with Arista Records, April 10, 1983.
item.description: The singer and the hit maker were entangled for three decades. He wanted chart-topping songs. But what did she want?
item.dc:creator: JACOB BERNSTEIN

item.title: The ‘Hustler’ vs. the Feminist Champion: Inside the ‘Battle of the Sexes’
item.media:description: Billie Jean King and Bobby Riggs in New York in July 1973.
item.description: The hype leading up to the tennis match between Billie Jean King and Bobby Riggs on Sept. 20, 1973, was over the top. Here’s a look at the coverage.
item.dc:creator: JACEY FORTIN

item.title: New Trailer: ‘Annihilation’ Puts Natalie Portman in Danger
item.media:description: Natalie Portman in a scene from the trailer for “Annihilation.”
item.description: The creepy sci-fi drama, based on a best-selling novel, is from Alex Garland, the director of “Ex Machina.”
item.dc:creator: BRUCE FRETTS

item.title: Review: Why the New ‘Flatliners’ Is Just ‘Meh’
item.media:description: Ellen Page and James Norton in “Flatliners.”
item.description: The original starred Julia Roberts, Kiefer Sutherland and Kevin Bacon, among others. The new one has Ellen Page and some horror movie tricks.
item.dc:creator: GLENN KENNY

item.title: New Book About Woody Allen Alleges Abusive Parenting by Mia Farrow
item.media:description: Mia Farrow this year.
item.description: In the book, Moses Farrow asserts that Ms. Farrow coached her daughter, Dylan Farrow, in accusing Mr. Allen of sexual abuse.
item.dc:creator: SOPAN DEB
item.category: Start to Finish: Woody Allen and the Art of Moviemaking (Book)

item.title: On DVD: ‘Othello’: Shakespeare’s Tragedy Was Orson Welles’s Triumph
item.media:description: Orson Welles in the title role in his “Othello.”
item.description: The director pieced together his masterpiece “Othello” over several years and continents, and then revisited it two decades later in a documentary about its making.
item.dc:creator: J. HOBERMAN

item.title: Director Behind ‘American Masters’ Tries Something New With ‘Spielberg’
item.media:description: From left, Paul Simon, Susan Lacy and Susan Steinberg in 1992 for the “American Masters” documentary “Paul Simon: Born at the Right Time.”
item.description: Susan Lacy, who pioneered the biographical documentary at PBS with “American Masters,’’ is rolling out a film about Steven Spielberg for HBO.
item.dc:creator: MIKE HALE

item.title: Streaming: FandangoNow Bridges the Theatrical Experience and Streaming
item.media:description: Taron Egerton in the new movie “Kingsman: The Golden Circle.” The streaming site FandangoNow is offering the original Kingsman film for a discounted price.
item.description: Going to the movies with Fandango and getting the movies at home with FandangoNow.
item.dc:creator: GLENN KENNY

item.title: Your Week in Culture: Katy Perry, Agnès Varda, the Guggenheim’s Chinese Art (Minus the Animals)
item.media:description: Katy Perry will be performing at Madison Square Garden on Oct. 2 and 6.
item.media:credit: Jody Rogac for The New York Times
item.description: Also the week of Oct. 1: Dave Malloy returns downtown, and “The Gifted” debuts on Fox.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.category: Bill T Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Co

item.title: Julie Taymor to Direct Gloria Steinem Biopic
item.media:description: Gloria Steinem, whose memoir will be the basis of a new Hollywood movie directed by Julie Taymor.
item.media:credit: Caitlin Ochs for The New York Times
item.description: Ms. Taymor will direct a film about the feminist icon Gloria Steinem’s formative years, written by Sarah Ruhl.
item.dc:creator: SOPAN DEB

item.title: Film Series in NYC This Week
item.media:description: Robert Mitchum and Jane Russell in “His Kind of Woman,” which is screening as part of the New York Film Festival’s Mitchum retrospective. See listing below.
item.description: Our guide to film series and special screenings.
item.dc:creator: BEN KENIGSBERG

item.title: Anne Jeffreys, Glamorous Ghost of ’50s TV, Is Dead at 94
item.media:description: Anne Jeffreys as a mischievous ghost and Leo G. Carroll as a stodgy banker in the 1950s CBS sitcom “Topper.”
item.description: Ms. Jeffreys, who had a long career in film, on television and on Broadway, was best known for playing the otherworldly Marion Kerby on “Topper.”
item.dc:creator: ANITA GATES

item.title: David Gordon Green Narrates a Scene From ‘Stronger’
item.description: The director discusses a sequence featuring Jake Gyllenhaal and Tatiana Maslany.
item.dc:creator: MEKADO MURPHY

item.title: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Stronger’
item.description: David Gordon Green narrates a sequence from the film featuring Jake Gyllenhaal as Jeff Bauman.

item.title: The ‘Blade Runner 2049’ Look: Sci-Fi Brought Back Down to Earth
item.media:description: Ryan Gosling in “Blade Runner 2049” and the sketch for his character’s jacket, meant to reflect the raincoat Harrison Ford wore in the first film.
item.media:credit: Stephen Vaughan/Warner Bros.; Sam Hudecki/Alcon Entertainment and Warner Bros.
item.description: The costume designer Renée April explains the thinking that went into the sequel — masks and collars that hide faces and sleeves that hide hands.
item.dc:creator: RACHEL LEE HARRIS

item.title: A Cher Musical Is Broadway-Bound
item.media:description: Cher in 2014. She will be depicted on Broadway in “The Cher Show,” a new musical.
item.media:credit: Harry Scull Jr./The Buffalo News, via Associated Press
item.description: “The Cher Show,” a musical that uses her songs to tell her life story, will open first in Chicago.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL PAULSON

item.title: Review: In ‘Realive,’ a Man Is Reanimated in 2084
item.media:description: Tom Hughes in “Realive,” about a man who freezes his body to escape terminal cancer.
item.description: This above-average science-fiction film, written and directed by Mateo Gil, plays like a “Black Mirror” episode combined with a solemn love story.
item.dc:creator: KEN JAWOROWSKI

item.title: Review: In ‘Different Flowers,’ a Runaway Bride Gets Help From Her Sister
item.media:description: Emma Bell, left, and Hope Lauren in “Different Flowers.”
item.description: The two siblings get on each other’s nerves and in each other’s business.
item.dc:creator: MONICA CASTILLO

item.title: Review: A Violent Accident Rocks a Friendship in ‘Super Dark Times’
item.media:description: Kevin Phillips’s debut feature, “Super Dark Times,” is set four years before the massacre at Columbine High School.
item.description: Kevin Phillips’s direction and fine acting from the cast elevate this tale centered on two high schoolers coping with tragedy.
item.dc:creator: TEO BUGBEE

item.title: Review: Winning Her Back on Deadline in ‘Literally, Right Before Aaron’
item.media:description: Justin Long and Cobie Smulders in “Literally, Right Before Aaron.”
item.description: In this disjointed rom-com, Justin Long plays a man invited to the wedding of his former paramour. He’s not going easily.
item.dc:creator: ANDY WEBSTER

item.title: Review: Seeking Connection in a Busy Town in ‘Autumn, Autumn’
item.media:description: Lee Se-rang and Yang Heung-ju in “Autumn, Autumn.”
item.description: This South Korean film follows lonely characters in a resort town.
item.dc:creator: JEANNETTE CATSOULIS

item.title: Review: In ‘The Untold Tales of Armistead Maupin,’ a Portrait of a Gifted Writer
item.media:description: The writer Armistead Maupin is the subject of a documentary directed by Jennifer M. Kroot.
item.description: The film, directed by Jennifer M. Kroot, illustrates how the novelist’s gay experience informed his art.
item.dc:creator: ANDY WEBSTER
item.category: The Untold Tales of Armistead Maupin (Movie)

item.title: Review: ‘Blood Stripe’ Finds a Woman Back From War, and Still Fighting
item.media:description: Kate Nowlin in “Blood Stripe.”
item.description: A former Marine returns home and battles with post-traumatic stress in this film.
item.dc:creator: KEN JAWOROWSKI

item.title: Review: ‘Let’s Play Two’ Takes Pearl Jam Out to the Ball Game
item.media:description: Eddie Vedder in “Let’s Play Two: Pearl Jam Live at Wrigley Field.”
item.description: Blending concert film and sports diary, Danny Clinch chronicles Pearl Jam’s pair of shows at Wrigley Field during the Cubs’ championship season.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL M. GOLD
item.category: Let's Play Two: Pearl Jam Live at Wrigley Field (Movie)

item.title: Review: An Inheritance Is Threatened in ‘Abundant Acreage Available’
item.media:description: Amy Ryan in “Abundant Acreage Available.”
item.description: Amy Ryan and Terry Kinney are siblings at the center of a land dispute in this film from Angus MacLachlan.
item.dc:creator: JEANNETTE CATSOULIS

item.title: Review: A Cranky Loner Faces Mortality in ‘Lucky’
item.media:description: Harry Dean Stanton in “Lucky.”
item.description: In one of his last roles, Harry Dean Stanton shines as a cantankerous old man.
item.dc:creator: JEANNETTE CATSOULIS

item.title: Jan Triska, Czech-American Actor Seen in ‘Ragtime,’ Dies at 80
item.media:description: Jan Triska in 2012.
item.media:credit: Josef Horazny/Czech News Agency, via Associated Press
item.description: Mr. Triska, who moved to the United States after he was banned by Czechoslovakia’s Communist government, fell from a bridge in Prague on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: The Record Bid for ‘Breakfast at Tiffany’s’ Script Is From Tiffany’s
item.media:description: An autographed photo of Audrey Hepburn and George Peppard in “Breakfast at Tiffany’s,” which was auctioned at Christie’s in London.
item.description: Audrey Hepburn’s 140-page typed script to the classic film brought the highest price for any film script at auction, Christie’s said.
item.dc:creator: SCOTT REYBURN

item.title: Viva: A Warhol-Era Superstar Wants the Last Word
item.media:description: Viva in Andy Warhol’s 90-minute film “San Diego Surf” (1968/1996). “The films were pretty boring,” she said.
item.description: The artist’s onetime muse and sidekick takes aim at her mentor, fake news and the F.B.I.
item.dc:creator: RUTH LA FERLA

item.title: Modern Love: Modern Love Podcast: Ali Fazal Reads ‘When Your Greatest Romance Is a Friendship’
item.description: On this week’s podcast, the “Victoria and Abdul” actor reads an essay about a relationship that transcends age.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: New York Film Festival Is a Feast for True Believers
item.media:description: Agnès Varda and JR in “Faces Places.”
item.description: The festival, at 55, retains a near-holy belief in cinema as art. Highlights: new work by Agnès Varda, Agnieszka Holland and Valeska Grisebach.
item.dc:creator: MANOHLA DARGIS
item.category: Did You Wonder Who Fired the Gun? (Movie)
